docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of Sybase Inc. lost a fourth of their value today after the company, a producer of data-base management software, said that it would report fourth-quarter results well below Wall Street analysts' estimates. The shortfall at Sybase comes less than a month after the Oracle Corporation, the leading independent data-base vendor, also reported disappointing results. With the Informix Corporation, the third major company in this market, mired in its own financial difficulties, analysts say the health of the entire data-base business is in question. The leading data-base producer, I.B.M., does not break out separate numbers for that business, but analysts say it too is probably experiencing some slowing of growth.
docs.abstract: Shares of Sybase Inc lose fourth of their value after company, producer of data-base management software, says that it will report fourth-quarter results well below Wall Street's analysts' estimates; graph shows decline in shares (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like so many other parents, they sent out a birth notice: ''Mario and Jane Simeone proudly announce the birth of their new arrivals!'' It listed the names of their triplets, the birth weights, lengths, and birth date: June 21, 1997. There were also color photographs, which conveyed what the words could not: Amber Raquel in the yellow light of a neonatal incubator, the word ''caution'' visible on its side; Cheyenne Barbara with tubes sprouting from chest, legs, arms and hands; Mario Victor with a ventilator tube taped to his mouth.

headline.main: Heartache Frequently Visits Parents With Multiple Births

docs.abstract: Joy surrounding birth of McCaughey septuplets in Des Moines compels some parents who have gone through difficult multiple births to disclose some of the heartache they have suffered; births of triplets, quadruplets and even quintuplets are becoming common thanks to new infertility treatments, and some of these pregnancies remain fraught with problems despite medical advances; parents involved in these pregnancies undergo frenzy of emotions; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In April, Bankers Trust, the nation's seventh-largest bank, agreed to buy Alex. Brown & Sons, a securities firm. That deal initiated a buying spree on Wall Street, culminating in the announcement in September that Travelers Group was buying Salomon Brothers Inc., adding more clout in bond trading and investment banking to an already flourishing combination of brokerage and insurance businesses. Those combinations worry some lawmakers, who note that the current regulatory structure for financial services was devised when securities firms were securities firms, insurers sold insurance and banks acted like banks. As a lowering of the financial services industry's traditional legal walls and competition for the consumer's dollar give rise to ever-bigger financial supermarkets, concern is rising about safeguards for investors and the financial system.

headline.main: Financial Services Consolidate, but Regulation Is Still Fragmented

docs.abstract: Concern is rising about safeguard for investors and financial system as financial services companies merge and industry consolidates; many experts say trend cries out for corresponding consolidation of regulatory structure, with creation of new umbrella organization that looks at financial services companies comprehensively rather than bit by bit; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: All Deborah Thompson really has is time, and a place to spend it. She lives in a tiny house in a part of town where the paint peels and the corner store still sells coal by the sack, and the funeral home is the nicest structure around. She does not have a social calendar, cable television, or a car.

headline.main: Comfort vs. Style in Town Clash on Porches

docs.abstract: Wilson, NC, is expected to ban old sofas and other indoor furniture from porches and yards; Southern historians see attack on long tradition of moving usable furniture outdoors when replaced by new furniture and on people who cannot afford patio furniture; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State of New York is scrambling to reprogram a computer that improperly denied medical insurance to at least hundreds of welfare recipients last month, officials said yesterday. The statewide computer system, which handles all welfare cases, mistakenly terminated Medicaid coverage for single adults on welfare who failed to comply with work requirements. A new state law, which took effect in November, prohibits counties from denying Medicaid to those people.

headline.main: Computer Error Cuts Off Some Entitled to Medicaid

docs.abstract: State of New York scrambles to reprogram computer that improperly denied medical insurance to hundreds of welfare recipients in December; statewide computer system, which handles all welfare cases, mistakenly terminated Medicaid coverage for single adults on welfare who failed to comply with work requirements; new state law prohibits counties from denying Mediciad to those people; state health and welfare officials attribute delay in reprogramming computer to sheer magnitude of changes now required under new state and Federal welfare laws (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The book ''Travels With Lizbeth'' propelled its author, Lars Eighner, to acclaim. Perhaps more importantly, into a home. ''Lizbeth'' was an account of three years that Mr. Eighner spent on the streets of Texas and California with his dog Lizbeth, a Labrador mix, foraging for food and sleeping under bridges. In a glowing appraisal on the cover of The New York Times Book Review in 1993, the reviewer, Jonathan Raban, said, ''If there's any justice in the world, it should guarantee its author a roof over his head for the rest of his days.''

headline.main: Almost Homeless Again: Writer and Dog on Edge

docs.abstract: Article on Lars Eighner, author of book Travels With Lizbeth, account of three years that Eighner spent on streets of Texas and California with his dog Lizbeth; says $100,000 that Eighner received from book lasted six years and provided him with housing until last October; Louis Dubose, editor of Texas Observer, with Michael King, his co-editor at The Observer, and about 35 local writers pitched in on Nov 24 and provided apartment for Eighner to get through winter; hope is that new assignments, past royalties and perhaps Social Security insurance will generate some security; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The White House's solution to signing up the millions of children who are eligible for Medicaid is ''simply to find eligible families, inform them of their rights and persuade them to apply'' (front page, Dec. 29). But if efforts are not linguistically and culturally appropriate, many poor, legal immigrant children will fall through the cracks. In 1996, 475,000 Asian-American children lacked health insurance nationwide. Despite the fact that Asian-American children are twice as likely to be poor as non-Hispanic whites, their Medicaid enrollment rates are virtually identical.
docs.abstract: Carolyn J Yu letter calls for outreach programs to enroll eligible uninsured Asian-American children in Medicaid (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The owners of dogs that bark in New York City will face tougher sanctions, female golfers in Connecticut will gain new privileges at their country clubs and smokers in New Jersey will pay higher tobacco taxes, as dozens of new laws take effect today in a mixed bag of new taxes, rights and prohibitions. In New York State, a law gives cats the same legal status as dogs, horses and cattle, at least when they are struck by a car or truck.

headline.main: To Usher In the New Laws, Quiet the Dog, Quit Smoking

docs.abstract: Dozens of new laws take effect on Jan 1 in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, in mixed bag of new taxes, rights and prohibitions (M)
